summary: Experienced biophysical researcher with experience in higher education. Applying biophysical techniques to increase our understanding of fundamental biology. Strong research professional with a Master of Science (M.Sc.) focused in Physics from University of Alberta. Personal fitness coach passionate about link between lifestyle factors and cognitive health. Meta-educator, teaching groups of people and organizations to learn more effectively through lifestyle adaptations and accelerated learning strategies.

awards.title: Pfizer AI challenges brainstorm
awards.description: Join this unique opportunity to engage with leading Health & Life Sciences company Pfizer. In an informal and intimate setting (maximum 5 teams of 4 can participate) students and researchers can discuss and develop angles to tackle some of the challenges Pfizer faces today. For students and researchers who understand the impact of Artificial Intelligence on today’s corporations. You don’t need an AI background to participate.

awards.title: Canadian 2019 Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) Rapid Research Funding Opportunity
awards.description: The new coronavirus 2019-nCoV has spread rapidly in the last 3 months, infecting tens of thousands of people in dozens of countries and killing over 1,000, with no preventive vaccines or medications that can treat it. We propose to search for possible drugs to treat 2019-nCoV by targeting the ability of the virus to hijack the cell's machinery and recode how the genome is read via programmed ribosomal frameshifting (PRF). Coronaviruses use PRF, which is triggered by a specific structure (a 'pseudoknot') in the viral genome, to produce essential enzymes in specific ratios. Suppressing PRF in SARS coronavirus-which is very closely related to 2019-nCoV-disrupts viral propagation and significantly reduces infectivity, suggesting that PRF inhibitors could be used to combat 2019-nCoV. We will search for potential drugs that bind to the 2019-nCoV pseudoknot and disrupt PRF. We will first build a structural model of the pseudoknot by combining computational simulations with measurements revealing the base-pairing patterns and higher-order structures in the RNA. We will then use high-throughput computational tools to screen large libraries of existing approved drugs (which could be deployed rapidly), as well as publicly-available chemical compounds, for binding to the pseudoknot. Compounds predicted to have high binding affinity will be tested experimentally to confirm their binding-quantifying the binding affinity, identifying the binding site, and showing that binding alters the pseudoknot structural dynamics (thought to be important for triggering PRF)-and to measure their effectiveness at inhibiting PRF in cell extracts. We will examine if the effects of the compounds are specific to 2019-nCoV by repeating all measurements using other RNA structures as controls. Lead compounds will be passed on to collaborators for future studies assessing their effectiveness against live virus and suitability for deployment as therapeutics.

profile_positions.description: Currently, I am studying gene regulation via programmed ribosomal frameshifting at a single-molecule level. Programmed ribosomal frameshifting (PRF) is a ubiquitous phenomenon used by organisms of all kingdoms of life, one whose impact is only recently been appreciated. PRF involves regulation of gene expression through changes in the process of translation whereby the information in RNA is used to produce proteins, much of the past research on gene regulation has focused on modifications at the level of transcription, going from DNA to RNA. Present research shows the importance of PRF in many processes, particularly in viral infection. My work is a multifaceted approach to understanding the process of frameshifting, with potential therapeutic innovations emerging. My work examines the mystery of what happens during the frameshift event, a not well understood process. Furthermore, we use insights from single-molecule studies of RNA elements known to induce PRF to lend insights into this arcane process. From this, we are examining anti-frameshifting compounds for their impact on frameshifting; potentially resulting in anti-viral therapeutics. Additionally, another minor project involves insights into the evolution of this process through bioinformatic tools.
